content: Malaysian & Indonesian traditional dessert **Kue kochi** or **koci** (also known as **passover cake** in English[*citation needed*]) is a [Maritime Southeast Asian](/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia) [dumpling](/wiki/Dumpling)-type [kuih](/wiki/Kuih) found in [Javanese](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine), [Malay](/wiki/Malay_cuisine) and [Peranakan cuisine](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine), typically made from [black glutinous rice](/wiki/Black_rice) flour, and stuffed with coconut fillings with [palm sugar](/wiki/Palm_sugar). In [Brunei](/wiki/Bruneian_cuisine), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine), this [snack](/wiki/Kue) is often as a [dessert](/wiki/Dessert) and can be eaten at anytime (during [breakfast](/wiki/Breakfast) or [tea time](/wiki/Tea_(meal))). The black colour of the unpolished rice symbolises death, while the sweet filling represents resurrection. - Food portal - Malaysia portal - Singapore portal - Indonesia portal - [Peranakan cuisine](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine) - [Mochi](/wiki/Mochi) - similar dessert in Japan made from glutinous rice flour. This [Indonesian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine)-related article is a stub. title: Kue kochi
